title: 103_s1720
content: The Act titled "Gambling Impact Study Commission Act" acknowledges the support for gambling industry development by various governments but also recognizes the problems it can bring. Congress establishes a commission to study the impact of gambling. The Gambling Impact Study Commission is established by the Act, with 9 members appointed by the President, Senate, and House of Representatives. Members serve for the life of the Commission, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Gambling Impact Study Commission, established by the Act, consists of 9 members appointed by the President, Senate, and House of Representatives. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, and subsequent meetings will be called by the Chairman. A majority of members constitutes a quorum, and the Commission will select a Chairman and Vice Chairman from among its members. A majority of members constitutes a quorum, and the Commission will select a Chairman and Vice Chairman from among its members. SEC. 4. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Gambling Impact Study Commission will conduct a thorough study on the impact of gambling on States, political subdivisions, and Native American tribes. The study will also explore alternative revenue sources for these entities. A report with detailed findings and conclusions must be submitted to the President and Congress within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Gambling Impact Study Commission will provide findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions related to the impact of gambling on States, political subdivisions, and Native American tribes. The Gambling Impact Study Commission has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. They can also request information from Federal agencies to carry out the provisions of the Act. Additionally, the Commission has authority over personnel matters. The Gambling Impact Study Commission members are compensated based on their status as federal government employees or not. Non-government members receive daily pay equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule, while government members serve without additional compensation. All members are entitled to travel expenses at authorized rates. The Chairman of the Gambling Impact Study Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The executive director's compensation is set at $75,000 annually, and other personnel's compensation can be determined by the Chairman without following specific regulations. The Chairman of the Gambling Impact Study Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and the Chairman may procure temporary services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will end 90 days after submitting its report. $250,000 is authorized for the Commission's expenses, with funds available indefinitely.
